Title: Take Our Word For it
Description: Richard Steinberg writes: Someone has asked me the origin of the word daemon as it applies to computing. Best I can tell based on my research, the word was ﬁrst used by people on your team at Project MAC using the IBM 7094 in 1963.” Professor Corbato replies: Our use of the word daemon was inspired by the Maxwell’s daemon of physics and thermodynamics (my background is in physics). Maxwell’s daemon was an imaginary agent which helped sort molecules of different speeds and worked tirelessly in the background. We fancifully began to use the word daemon to describe background processes which worked tirelessly to perform system chores.”

Title: Before Memory Was Virtual
AuthorList: Peter Denning. In the Beginning: Recollections of Software Pioneers, Wiley, November 1997.
Description: An excellent historical piece by one of the pioneers of virtual memory and working sets.

Title: Idleness is not sloth
AuthorList: Richard Golding, Peter Bosch, Carl Staelin, Tim Sullivan, John Wilkes. USENIX ATC ’95, New Orleans, Louisiana.
Description: A fun and easy-to-read discussion of how idle time can be better used in systems, with lots of good examples.

Title: Virtual Memory Management in the VAX/VMS Operating System
AuthorList: Hank Levy, P. Lipman. IEEE Computer, Vol. 15, No. 3, March 1982.
Description: Not the ﬁrst place where page clustering was used, but a clear and simple explanation of how such a mechanism works. We sure cite this paper a lot!
